article.title: List of Hebrew Bible manuscripts
article.text:
[[File:LeningradCodex text.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Leningrad Codex text sample, portions of Exodus 15:21-16:3]]
A '''Hebrew Bible manuscript''' is a handwritten copy of a portion of the text of the [[Hebrew Bible]] ([[Tanakh]]) made on papyrus, parchment, or paper, and written in the [[Hebrew language]]. (Some of the Biblical text and notations may be in [[Aramaic]].) The oldest manuscripts were written in a form of scroll, the medieval manuscripts usually were written in a form of [[codex]]. The late manuscripts written after the 9th century use the [[Masoretic Text]]. The important manuscripts are associated with [[Aaron ben Moses ben Asher|Aaron ben Asher]] (especially [[Codex Leningradensis]]).<ref>H. Kelley, Daniel Stephen Mynatt, Timothy G. Crawford, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Gh6OHYcIZgkC&pg=PA18&lpg=#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Masorah of Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia: introduction and annotated glossary''], Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing, 1998, p. 18</ref>

The original manuscripts and early copies of the Old Testament disappeared over time, because of wars, (especially the destruction of the First and Second Temples), and other intentional destructions.<ref>Randall Price, [https://books.google.com/books?id=R7ZHjZencgIC&pg=PA45&lpg=#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Searching for the Original Bible''], Harvest House Publishers, 2007, p. 45-50</ref> As a result, the lapse of time between the original manuscripts and their surviving copies is much longer than in the case of the [[New Testament]] [[Biblical manuscript#New Testament manuscripts|manuscripts]].

The first list of the Old Testament manuscripts in Hebrew, made by [[Benjamin Kennicott]] (1776–1780) and published by Oxford, listed 615 manuscripts from libraries in England and on the Continent.<ref>Thomas Hartwell Horne, [https://books.google.com/books?id=pMUVAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA7&lpg= ''An introduction to the critical study and knowledge of the Holy Scriptures''] (1836), vol. 2, p. 7</ref> [[Giovanni de Rossi]] (1784–1788) published a list of 731 manuscripts.<ref name = lakeside>[http://www.lakesideministries.com/TopicalStudies/Foundations/OldTestament.htm#OLD%20TESTAMENT%20MANUSCRIPTS Old Testament manuscripts]</ref> The main manuscript discoveries in modern times are those of the [[Cairo Geniza]] (c. 1890) and the Dead Sea Scrolls (1947). In the old synagogue in [[Cairo]] were discovered 260,000 Hebrew manuscripts, 10,000 of which are biblical manuscripts.<ref>[http://www.bibliahebraica.com.br/textos/Gueniza_do_Cairo.pdf ''Fragmentos do Gueniza do Cairo'']{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>David Sinclair, [http://www.davidsinclairmc.com/christianarticles/AN%20OVERVIEW%20OF%20THE%20BIBLE%20-%20Version%20II.pdf#page=15 ''An Overview of the Bible''] (2006)</ref> There are more than 200 biblical manuscripts among the [[Dead Sea Scrolls]], some of them were written in the [[Paleo-Hebrew alphabet]]. They were written before the year 70 AD. 14 scroll manuscripts were discovered in [[Masada]] in 1963–1965.<ref>Würthwein Ernst (1988). ''Der Text des Alten Testaments'', Stuttgart: [[Deutsche Bibelgesellschaft]], pp. 38–39; translated into English and published in 1995 as Wurthwein, ''The Text of the Old Testament'' (2nd rev. ed, 1995, Grand Rapids, Mich., Wm.B. Eerdmans Publg. Co.)(this is the source for most of the dates of the mss listed).</ref>

The largest organized collection of Hebrew Old Testament manuscripts in the world is housed in the [[Russian National Library]] ("Second Firkovitch Collection") in [[Saint Petersburg]].<ref name = lakeside/>

[[Codex Leningradensis]] is the oldest complete manuscript of the Hebrew Bible in Hebrew. Manuscripts earlier than the 13th century are very rare. The majority of the manuscripts have survived in a fragmentary condition.

== Masorah manuscripts ==
* [[Severus Scroll]] (named for the Roman Emperor who restored this scroll, reportedly seized from the Temple in Jerusalem, to the Jewish community in 220), a lost manuscript of early 1st century AD, only a few sentences are preserved by [[Rabbinic literature]]
* Codex Hilleli, a lost manuscript of circa 600 AD, destroyed in 1197 in Spain, only a few sentences are preserved by Rabbinic literature<ref>{{cite book |title=The text of the Old Testament: an introduction to the Biblia Hebraica |last=Würthwein |first=Ernst |year=1995 |publisher= Eerdmans Publishing |isbn=978-0-8028-0788-5 |page=38 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FSNKSBObCYwC&pg=PA38#v=onepage&q&f=false }}</ref>
* Codex Muggeh (or Muga)(="corrected"), lost, cited as a source in Massoretic notations.
* [[Codex Orientales 4445]], also known as "London Codex",<ref>[http://britishlibrary.typepad.co.uk/asian-and-african/2014/04/45-hebrew-manuscripts-go-digital.html# British Library Asian and African studies blog 10 April 2014]</ref> dated 820-850 AD; the manuscript contains Genesis-Deuteronomy 1:33 (less Numbers 7:47–73 and Numbers 9:12–10:18).<ref>Manuscript written by two different scribes, the older square script believed to be from the 9th century, whereas the newer Yemenite square script was written in the 16th century. See the British Library, [http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Or_4445 Or. 4445].</ref>
* [[Codex Cairensis]], (Prophets) pointed by Moses Ben Asher, dated by a colophon 895 AD (the oldest manuscript bearing the date of its writing), (was in Cairo, now in Jerusalem)
* [[Codex Babylonicus Petropolitanus]], (Latter Prophets) dated 916 AD, [[Russian National Library]]
* [[Aleppo Codex]], 930 AD, [[Israel Museum]], (was complete, supposedly pointed by Aaron Ben Asher, partly destroyed in 1947); this manuscript is the basis of the ''[[Jerusalem Crown]]'' bible.
* [[Codex Leningradensis]], (complete) copied from a Ben Asher manuscript, dated 1008 AD, [[Russian National Library]]; this manuscript is the basis of the ''[[Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia]]'' and other editions.
* Michigan Codex, (Torah) 10th century<ref>Eleazar Birnbaum, ''The Michigan Codex: An important Hebrew Bible manuscript'', Vetus Testamentum, vol. 17 pages 373-415 (Oct. 1967).</ref>
* [[Damascus Pentateuch|Damascus Keter]] (Damascus Pentateuch), 10th century<ref>[http://www.wdl.org/en/item/11364/ Damascus Pentateuch]</ref>
* [[Codex Reuchlinanus]] (Prophets), dated 1105 AD.
* Codex Yerushalmi, lost, reportedly used in Spain (circa 1010) by [[Jonah ibn Janah]].
* Erfurt Codices (complete, Berlin), E1 circa 14th century, E2 possibly 13th century, E3 possibly 11th century
* Scroll 2, dated AD 1155-1255, University of Bologna Library
* Codex Jericho, (Pentateuch) lost, cited in the notes to a Massoretic manuscript written circa 1310.
* Codex Ezra, lost, C.D. Ginsburg owned a manuscript written in 1474 which purported to have been copied from this.
* Codex Sinai, mentioned in Massoretic notes and reportedly used by [[Elia Levita]] (circa 1540).
* Codex Sanbuki (named for Zambuqi, on the Tigris River), lost, frequently quoted in Massoretic annotations and apparently seen (circa 1600) by [[Menahem Lonzano]].
* Codex Great Mahzor, lost, mentioned in Massoretic notes (the title suggests that this codex contained only the Pentateuch and those selections from the Prophets that were read during the liturgical year)
* Ben Asher Manuscripts.

== Modern discoveries ==
* [[Nash Papyrus]], dated to the 2nd BC – 1st AD
* [[Cairo Geniza]] fragments contains portions of the Old Testament in Hebrew and Aramaic, discovered in Cairo synagogue, which date from about 4th century AD

=== Dead Sea Scrolls ===
Dated Between 250 BC and 70 AD.<ref>Timothy Lim, ''The Dead Sea Scrolls: A Very Short Introduction'', Oxford University Press, 2005, ''Dating the Scrolls'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=4GwEtg6jnLMC&pg=PT55]</ref>
* [[Isaiah scroll]], 1Qlsa, contains almost the complete text of the [[Book of Isaiah]] 
* [[4Q41|4QDeut<sup>n</sup>]], contains the [[Ten Commandments|Decalogue]].
* [[4Q106]]
* [[4Q107]]
* [[4Q108]]
* [[4Q240]]
* [[6Q6]]

== References ==
{{Reflist}}

== Further reading ==
* Würthwein Ernst (1988). ''Der Text des Alten Testaments'', Stuttgart: [[Deutsche Bibelgesellschaft]] 1988, p. 40–47; English translation [https://books.google.com/books?id=FSNKSBObCYwC&pg=PA0&lpg=#v=onepage&q&f=false The text of the Old Testament: an introduction to the Biblia Hebraica]
* Malcolm C. Davis, Ben Outhwaite, [https://books.google.com/books?id=lZtxUICXIP4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false '' Hebrew Bible Manuscripts in the Cambridge Genizah Collections: Taylor-Schechter additional series 32–255, with addenda to previous volumes''], [[Cambridge University Library]] 2003
* Bernhard Pick, ''Lost Hebrew Manuscripts'', Journal of the Society of Biblical Literature, [http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.b3374270;view=1up;seq=342;q1=%22lost%20hebrew%20manuscripts%22;start=1;size=10;page=search;num=122] vol. 2, pages 122-127 (1882).
* C. David Ginsburg, ''Introduction to the Massoretico-Critical Edition of the Hebrew Bible'' (1897, London: Trinitarian Bible Society), [https://archive.org/details/introductionofma00ginsuoft] especially chapt. XII, History and Description of the Manuscripts, pages 469-778, and elsewhere in the volume for information on lost mss.
* [[Paul Kahle]], ''The Hebrew Ben Asher Manuscripts'', Vetus Testamentum, vol. 1, pages 161-167 (July 1951); mentions the Leningrad Codex, the Aleppo Codex, the Cairo Prophets (Codex Cairensis), and British Museum Or. 4445.
* [Emil G. Hirsch],"Bible Manuscripts", ''Jewish  Encyclopedia'' (1902)[http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/3265-bible-manuscripts] volume 3, pages 178-181, includes information on lost mss.
* Adolph Neubauer, ''The Introduction of the Square Characters in Biblical Manuscripts and an Account of the Earliest Manuscripts of the Old Testament'', Studia Biblica et Ecclesiastica [http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015043619827;seq=15;view=1up;num=2](Oxford Univ.), vol. 3, pages 1–36 (1891).
